CatDescriptText: Mr. Edgar Holt, night supervisor, Waring Court and Mr. Robert Skop, freight handler, Oakdale, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in the Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, September 30, 1961, pg. 7 with question: "Do you think the United States should go to war with Russia over Berlin?"  Mr. Holt's answer reads: "War never solved any problem; so shy should we, think of it as a solution of the Berlin problem.  Such a was would mean total destruction.  There should be some means of peaceably settling the problem.  However, if it came to a point where war was imminent, we shouldn't back down."  Mr. Skop's answer reads: "Yes, if it would lead to a settlement of the present day trouble, but we should do so only if forced into it.  We should show our hand only when forced and we know that the other nations would support us...Our President is showing his hand so far, whereas I think that Ike was a little too easy..."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Edgar Holt wearing hat and light colored striped button down collared shirt with pens and eyeglass case, standing in front of building on Smithfield Street, Downtown; Portrait of Robert Skop wearing plaid shirt and hat, standing in front of ribbed metal wall
